Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Linking climate-driven changes in erosion to tectonic processes along the southern Alaska Margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most challenging questions in active mountain building is how climate might drive tectonic processes, in the form of mass redistribution. In other words, do climate-driven changes in erosion lead to increased exposure of mountainous belts, and perhaps influence tectonic processes, like uplift and faulting, as predicted by numerical models? The study of this question, by means of observational and analytical data is challenging because most areas where active mountain building is occurring are covered by remnant glaciers and glaciated landscapes from the end of the Neogene period (23 ? 2.5 million years ago). The St. Elias mountain belt, in southeast Alaska, is a prime location to address this question due to its extensive glaciation. The recent erosional record of this active mountain range is stored in the Gulf of Alaska and was recovered during Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 341. Integrated analysis of deep-sea core material obtained from drilling at the continental shelf, slope, and the deep-sea Surveyor Fan will provide means to quantify the effect of global and local climate changes on the erosional and structural evolution of a mountain range. The youthfulness of the St. Elias belt, along with high rates of tectonic and erosional processes, and its close proximity of the Gulf of Alaska provide an ideal natural setting to study climate-tectonic interactions.

Long-standing debates exist in the Earth sciences on whether Neogene climate change affects rates of surface processes, such as erosion, and consequently influences tectonic processes, such as faulting, through redistribution of mass. The proposed study will test the hypothesis that an increase in glacial erosion has led to focused exhumation in the core of the St. Elias orogeny as proposed by numerical and analytical data. Two possible target regions have been suggested where a tectonic-climate feedback may have developed: in the fold-thrust belt and at the indenting Yakutat plate corner. The wealth of existing onshore geo- and thermochronological data provide a comprehensive picture of the current spatial pattern of exhumation rates, but the quantification of changes in rates and patterns through time has been challenging. The research team?s approach is to investigate the offshore sedimentary record of the St. Elias orogeny deposited in the Gulf of Alaska. This orogeny developed during a period of significant global climate change, including the intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciation (iNHG) at the Plio-Pleistogene transition (PPT), ~2.6 Ma, and the mid-Pleistocene transition (MPT) from 1.2 to 0.7 Ma, but also a change of local climate resulting in alpine glaciers, perhaps as early as the Late Miocene/Pliocene (6.5 Ma). The high-resolution magnetostratigraphic and biostratigraphic age control from the IODP Expedition 341 cores allow close linking of changes in sedimentary lithofacies and textures, provenanace, exhumation, and sediment routing and distribution, to test the record of climate-tectonic interactions along the southern Alaska margin. The integration of Gulf of Alaska seismic reflection data with the age and provenance control from the 341 cores allow examination of sediment mass flux in the regional offshore depositional system, the Surveyor Fan, from a 3-D perspective through time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In coastal Alaska, the landscape of today has evolved over the last 2.6 million years through the interaction of mountain building and surface processes dominated by glaciation. The project investigated the glacial sediment record deposited in the Gulf of Alaska in boreholes drilled during IODP Expedition 341. A transect of sites from the continental shelf to the distal deep-sea archives the glacial history that is not preserved onshore in the eroded landscape of the St. Elias Mountains.

 The sediment flux from the Northwestern Cordilleran ice sheet in this region proves to be the highest recorded globally and shows evidence of seaward sediment transport by sediment gravity flows, meltwater plumes and icebergs. Dominance of biogenic sediment is indicated by intervals with diatom ooze deposition and volcanic eruptions are recorded in tephra layers. Preservation of foraminifera allowed shipboard chronologies to be augmented with oxygen isotopes and radiocarbon to produce an exceptionally well-dated sedimentary record.  

 The ice-rafted component, specifically the abundance of coarse sand (250µm-2mm) within these records was used to determine the onset, origin and characteristics of glaciation in coastal Alaska. In the deep sea, ice rafting began near the Plio-Pleistocene boundary (2.6 Ma) and continued through the mid-Pleistocene transition (1.2-0.7 Ma) to approximately 14,800 cal years B.P, when marine-ending glaciers terminated. Because of the high sediment flux, sites on the continental slope only extend back 100,000 years, thus recording the last glacial cycle. The ice rafted debris (IRD) mass accumulation rate (MAR) curve shows collapses of the Bering Ice Stream, the largest outlet glacier of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet bounded by periods without IRD. Perennial sea ice was present during a few discrete periods and at terminal glacial retreat indicated by the presence of sea ice-related diatoms and non-glacial microtextures on quartz sand grains. Peaks in both proxies suggest that sea ice intensified during and after IRD MAR peaks and may correspond with low salinity meltwater associated with large quantities of icebergs. The provenance of IRD sourced from the nearby Bering Glacier drainage basin includes terranes composed of sedimentary and low-grade metamorphic rocks and basalt. High-grade metamorphic rocks and specifically granitoid and marble originated from southeast Alaska. Therefore, IRD with a plutonic composition or marble likely traveled within the Alaskan Coastal Current on icebergs originating from glaciers to the east of the Bering Glacier, such as Malaspina and Hubbard. Small, high frequency IRD MAR peaks occur that include debris from far-traveled sources along the Alaskan coastline. This appears to represent a period without sea ice when icebergs could freely travel along the coast from Southeast Alaska and British Columbia. 

 Another important result of this study is documentation that iron input from icebergs occurs across the Mid Pleistocene transition by correlation of diatom blooms with peaks in IRD MAR. In high-nutrient, low chlorophyll oceans, such as in the subarctic Pacific, phytoplankton growth is critically iron-limited. Increased bioavailable iron supplied by aeolian dust from glacier-free land areas has been suggested to stimulate phytoplankton growth and drawdown carbon dioxide. This new observation appears to extend this process to include glacial periods with high IRD MAR.

 Six undergraduate students were associated with this research project through training in a variety of analytical techniques, data interpretation and presentations at regional and national conferences. Several of these research students have graduated after completing senior theses.
